solution_line_template: Marge used half the ${total_lottery_winnings} for taxes, so she had {total_lottery_winnings} / {tax_divisor} = $<<{total_lottery_winnings}/{tax_divisor}={money_after_taxes}>>{money_after_taxes} left.

She used 1/3 of the leftover money on student loans, so she paid {money_after_taxes} / {student_loan_divisor} = $<<{money_after_taxes}/{student_loan_divisor}={paid_for_student_loans}>>{paid_for_student_loans}.
After paying the student loans, she had {money_after_taxes} - {paid_for_student_loans} = $<<{money_after_taxes}-{paid_for_student_loans}={money_after_student_loans}>>{money_after_student_loans} left.
She put ${savings_amount} in savings, so she had {money_after_student_loans} - {savings_amount} = $<<{money_after_student_loans}-{savings_amount}={money_after_savings}>>{money_after_savings} left.
She invested {savings_amount} / {investment_divisor} = $<<{savings_amount}/{investment_divisor}={invested_amount}>>{invested_amount} in the stock market.
After investing, she had {money_after_savings} - {invested_amount} = $<<{money_after_savings}-{invested_amount}={money_left_for_fun}>>{money_left_for_fun} left for fun.
